chapter.title: Introduction to Linux Containers
chapter.para: Linux containers offer a lightweight virtualization method to run multiple virtual environments (containers) simultaneously on a single host. This is similar to the environment. Containers are isolated with kernel Control Groups () and kernel Namespaces.

Containers provide virtualization at the operating system level, where the kernel controls the isolated containers. This approach differs from full virtualization solutions like &xen; or &kvm;, where the processor simulates a complete hardware environment and controls virtual machines.
Conceptually, containers can be seen as an improved technique. While a chroot environment separates only the file system, containers go further and provide resource management and control via .

listitem.para: Provide nearly native performance, as containers manage allocation of resources in real time.
Control network interfaces and apply resources inside containers through .
Containers run inside the host system's kernel, thus they cannot use different kernels or different kernel versions.
Only Linux-based applications can be containerized.
